context:
[5] On the basis of a detailed kinetic modeling substudy performed at the 4- and 36-month visits, a modified rate equation (eKt/V = spKt/V âˆ’ 0.4 K/V [+0.01 for patients in the high-dose group]) was later developed and used to present the study results .  [6] In this report, standard Kt/V is estimated for each kinetic modeling session using a two-step calculation.  [7] In the first step, an approximation to stdKt/V (denoted S) was obtained using a simplified, fixed-volume equation :


(1) where N = 3, the number of treatments per week in the HEMO Study, t denotes treatment time in minutes, and eKt/V was computed using a modification of the Tattersall equation  given by eKt/V = spKt/V Ã— [T/(T + 23.2)], where the time constant of 23.2 minutes corresponds closely to the 0.40 term in the modified Daugirdas-Schneditz equation .  [8] In the second step, stdKt/V was corrected for ultrafiltration by: stdKt/V = S/(1 âˆ’ [0.74/N] Ã— Qfw/V) , where N again denotes the number of dialysis sessions per week, Qfw is the weekly fluid ingestion, and V is the modeled urea volume.  [9] This two-step procedure yields estimates of delivered stdKt/V, which closely approximate those provided by an exact solution to the two-pool variable extracellular volume model if the intercompartmental clearance, Kc in ml/min, is assumed to be 0.016 times the postdialysis modeled two-pool volume, in milliliters . [10] The stdKt/V estimates obtained by this approximation reflect delivered dialysis dose, and thus exclude residual renal urea clearance, which by design was small in HEMO Study subjects (<1.5 ml/min at entry).  [1] We used three different approaches to calculate surface-area-normalized stdKt/V (SAn-stdKt/V).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea is mentioned in relation to the calculation of standard Kt/V, which is a measure used in dialysis to assess the adequacy of treatment. The term 'ingestion' refers to the weekly fluid intake (Qfw) that influences the urea volume in the modeling of dialysis. While both terms are related to the dialysis process, the context does not provide a direct interaction or significant relationship between urea and ingestion beyond their roles in the calculations for dialysis adequacy.
